tn.text: See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]]
"through the action of Jeremiah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: cause them to listen ... cause them to listen
tn.text: The repetition of this phrase emphasizes the importance of the command. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Bel is made ashamed. Merodach is dismayed. Its idols are put to shame; its images are dismayed.
tn.text: These lines mean the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh has disgraced the gods of Babylon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
These are the two names for the chief god of Babylon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The word "it" refers to Babylon.
The word "her" refers to Babylon.
The word "it" refers to the land of Babylon.

tn.ref: In those days and at that time
tn.text: See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:33:14|33:15]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
The word "They" refers to people of Israel or people of Judah.
This is figurative language used to explain a spiritual connection to Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This states that the covenant will be obeyed forever. AT: "that no one will forget" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This compares the people of Israel to a group of sheep that are lost. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This compares destroying and taking everything from them to eating eagerly. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "they" refers to the people of Israel.
This compares the people whom Yahweh advises to leave as soon as possible from Babylon to male goats that tend to wander from the flock. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Babylon will be captured from there
tn.text: "The nations will capture Babylon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|01:8]].

tn.ref: you jump around like a calf stamping in its pasture
tn.text: This compares the people of Babylon to a calf who runs around joyfully in a meadow. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
See how you translated this in Jeremiah [[:en:bible:notes:jer:47:03|47:3]].

tn.ref: you neigh like a powerful horse
tn.text: This compares their happiness to the happiness of stallions that are neighing - making loud noises. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: So your mother will be greatly ashamed; the one who bore you will be embarrassed
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of her embarrassment. The words "mother" and "the one who bore you" refer either to Babylonia or to the city of Babylon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: a wilderness, a dry land, and a desert
tn.text: These words have basically the same meaning and emphasize the complete barrenness of the land. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
shake violently due to fear
make a sound like a snake that means great disapproval
Yahweh tells the enemies of Babylon how to conquer.
This refers to the soldiers who use bows and arrows to fight. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The word "her" refers to Babylon.
AT: "The nations have torn down her walls" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Yahweh tells the enemies of Babylon how to conquer.

tn.ref: the one who uses a sickle at the time of harvest
tn.text: A "sickle" is farm tool that people use to harvest grain. Together with the previous phrase, Yahweh is saying that all planting and harvesting will stop in Babylon.

tn.ref: Let each person turn back to his own people ... let them flee to their own land
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Together they strengthen the command for foreigners to flee Babylon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Here the word "sword" refers to the armies that will attack Babylon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Israel is a sheep scattered and driven away by lions
tn.text: AT: "Israel is a sheep that lions scattered and drove away" Yahweh compares Israel to sheep and her enemies to lions. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This compares the destruction of Israel by Assyria to being eaten eagerly. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This compares the destruction of Israel by Nebuchdnezzar to breaking bones. AT: "destroyed Israel". (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "See" means to pay special attention to what follows.
The word "I" refers to Yahweh.

tn.ref: he will graze on Carmel and Bashan
tn.text: "Israel will feed on the foods of Carmel and Bashan."

tn.ref: In those days and at that time
tn.text: See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:33:14|33:15]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: iniquity will be looked for in Israel, but none will be found. I will inquire about the sins of Judah, but none will be found
tn.text: These two lines mean basically the same thing. Together they emphasize that Yahweh will forgive the sins of the people of Israel completely. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: iniquity will be looked for in Israel, but none will be found
tn.text: AT: "Yahweh will look for iniquity in the people of Israel, but will not find any" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is another name for Babylon. This is a name that means "double rebellion". (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is another name for the Chaldeans. This is a name that means "visitation." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This refers to having a sword come down on people to kill them. AT: "kill them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|01:8]].

tn.ref: How the hammer of all the lands has been cut apart and destroyed
tn.text: Here, "the hammer of all the lands" is the powerful army of Babylon that is going to be destroyed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
a very strong feeling of fear, dread, and shock
AT: "I have captured you, Babylon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
AT: "I have found and seized you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
buildings where grain is stored

tn.ref: pile her up like heaps of grain
tn.text: AT "pile up what is left of her the way heaps of grain are piled up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Yahweh continues telling how to destroy the people of Babylon and Chaldea.
The young warriors are compared to bulls because of their strength. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "her" refers to Babylon.
The word "them" and "their" refer to the people of Babylon.
The word "those" and "These" refer to the survivors from Babylon who will tell others about Yahweh's vengeance.
Yahweh continues telling how to destroy the people of Babylon and Chaldea.
The words "her" and "she" refer to Babylon.

tn.ref: her fighting men will be destroyed
tn.text: AT: "I will destroy her fighting men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This word introduces something for special attention.
This is Yahweh's description of Babylon.

tn.ref: for your day has come ... the time when I will punish you
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The second phrase defines the "day" that the first phrase mentions. AT: "for the day when I will punish you has come." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
This refers to the span of time during the horrible judgment will come onto Babylon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The word "I" refers to Yahweh.
This refers to the way the destruction will come. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: The people of Israel are oppressed
tn.text: AT: "The Babylonians are oppressing the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The word "them" refers to the people of Israel.
The word "they" refers to the Babylonians.
The word "them" refers to the people of Israel.

tn.ref: A sword is against the Chaldeans
tn.text: "Sword" represents those who use them. AT: "enemy soldiers with swords are coming against the Chaldeans" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|01:8]].
The word "reveal" shows that their actions are foolish and will be exposed so everyone can see.

tn.ref: they will be filled with terror
tn.text: AT: "terror will fill them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"they will all become as weak as women" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
A storeroom is a place where valuables are kept.
AT: "enemy soldiers will plunder them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"Waters" represent all the sources of water and other necessities for life, especially the river that went through the city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
A jackal is a wild dog found in Asia and Africa.
"Ostriches" are very large African birds that run fast but cannot fly. The word "her" refers to Babylon.

tn.ref: For all time, she will no longer be inhabited. From generation to generation, she will not be lived in.
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that Babylon will be completely uninhabited. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: she will not be lived in
tn.text: AT: "no one will live in her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: no one will live there; no person will stay in her
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that Babylon will be completely uninhabited. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This word says to pay special attention to what Yahweh will say.

tn.ref: a great nation and many kings
tn.text: This phrase refers to the time when the Medes and Persians conquered Babylon in 539 BC.
the way troops are lined up in battle
This phrase refers to the Babylonian people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Anguish seizes him like a woman in labor
tn.text: The anguish of the king of Babylon is compared to the kind of anguish a woman experiences when she is in labor. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
suffering and grief that would bring one to tears.
The word "behold" here adds emphasis to what follows.
The word "he" refers to the invader from the north. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:jer:50:41|50:41]])
This is another way of saying that the attack will be fierce and unexpected. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: I will quickly cause them to run from it
tn.text: The word "them" refers to the people of Babylon; the word "it" refers to the invasion.
AT: someone I will chose" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: who is like me, and who will summon me?
tn.text: Yahweh uses the question to point out the smallness of humans. AT: "No one is like me, no one orders me around." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
order someone to come

tn.ref: What shepherd is able to resist me?
tn.text: Yahweh uses the question to show that no leader is able to come against him or defeat him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: the plans that Yahweh has decided against Babylon, the plans that he has planned against the land of the Chaldeans
tn.text: These two phrases have the same meaning and are used together for emphasis. AT: "the plans that Yahweh has decided for the people of Babylon and the Chaldeans". (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: They will certainly be dragged away
tn.text: This means that the people of Babylon will be taken from their homes whether they like it or not. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Their pasturelands will be turned into ruined places
tn.text: "I will turn their pasturelands into ruined places" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: At the sound of conquered Babylon the earth shakes
tn.text: This phrase compares the fall of the once powerful nation of Babylon to an extremely loud noise and earthquake. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
pain or unhappiness
"their shout of pain"
